titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Alice Raphael Papers
titlestmt.author: by Molly Wheeler

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Wednesday March 27, 2019 at 03:05

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The Alice Raphael Papers contain writings, translations, correspondence, lectures, photographs, a scrapbook and other papers that document the professional and personal life of author and translator Alice Raphael. The papers include letters from Carl Gustav Jung and drafts of Raphael's book Goethe and the Philosophers' Stone: Symbolical Patterns in 'The Parable' and the Second Part of 'Faust' and her translation of Goethe's Faust: A Tragedy Part One and Faust: A Tragedy Part Two . The papers span the years 1918-1977.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Alice Raphael Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Alice Raphael Papers. Yale Collection of German Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Correspondence comprising Series V. was transferred from the administrative files of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library by curatorial staff.

bioghist.head: Alice Raphael (1887-1975)
bioghist.p: Alice Pearl Raphael was born on June 22, 1887 in Brownsville, Texas. She attended Barnard College in New York City and studied music in Germany. Raphael later lived in Zurich and studied with Carl Gustav Jung and Fritz Wittels and was a lay analyst for several years. Raphael focused for many years on her translation of Johann Wolfgang von Goethe's Faust: A Tragedy Part One and Faust: A Tragedy Part Two . Her friend William A. Speck, curator of his own collection at Yale University's Collection of German Literature, assisted her in the translation until his death in 1928. Carl Schreiber, who oversaw the Speck Collection following Speck's death, befriended Raphael and continued assistance with her translations. In 1939, Raphael met Curt von Faber du Faur, who in 1944 became curator of Yale's Collection of German Literature and university faculty member. Raphael and Faber du Faur were close colleagues and friends until Faber du Faur died in 1966.

Raphael published several articles, reviews, and the 1965 book Goethe and the Philosophers' Stone: Symbolical Patterns in 'The Parable' and the Second Part of 'Faust' . This book analyses Goethe in the context of Jungian theory. In the 1920s, Raphael was interested in drawing and studied drawing in Washington, CT. She preferred colored pencils and expressed herself through a method that she called "spontaneous creative expression."

Raphael lived in Manhattan for most of her life, where she founded the Analytical Psychology Club of New York and was an active member of the Society for Psychical Research. She married Henry Eckstein in 1911 and had two daughters. Raphael died in Manhattan on August 27, 1975.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Alice Raphael Papers contain writings, translations, correspondence, lectures, photographs, a scrapbook and other papers that document the professional and personal life of author and translator Alice Raphael. Writings and translations comprise the bulk of the papers. Raphael's writings include drafts for her book Goethe and the Philosophers' Stone: Symbolical Patterns in 'The Parable' and the Second Part of 'Faust.' The papers contain several drafts of Raphael's translation of Goethe's Faust: A Tragedy Part One and Two with annotations and notes that reveal her translation process. Correspondence primarily consists of correspondence with Carl Gustav Jung, William A. Speck, Curt von Faber du Faur, and other curators of the Yale Collection of German Literature. The bulk of the correspondence regards her work to publish her Goethe translation and her writings on Goethe. The papers also contain sound recordings of Raphael's 1965 lectures given at the New York Institute of the C. G. Jung Foundation for Analytical Psychology. Photographs include portraits of Raphael and an album of snapshots of the Eckstein family and their farm in Greenwich, CT. The papers also include a scrapbook of Raphael's colored pencil drawings and a charcoal portrait of Raphael by Kahlil Gibran.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The papers are organized into five series: Writings and Translations, Correspondence, Lectures, Other Papers, Correspondence with Yale Collection of German Literature.

controlaccess.persname: Raphael, Alice, 1887-1975 ( Goethe and the philosophers stone)

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series I, Writings and Translations is arranged into four subseries: Goethe and the Philosophers' Stone: Symbolical Patterns in 'The Parable' and the Second Part of 'Faust' , Other Writings, Translations, and Writings by Others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains drafts of Raphael's writings and translations of selected works by Johann Wolfgang von Goethe. Drafts of Goethe and the Philosophers' Stone: Symbolical Patterns in 'The Parable' and the Second Part of 'Faust' are accompanied by reports written by Graham Munson and H. Popper, and a letter from Munson regarding the book. Other writings include drafts of Raphael's writings on Goethe and Thomas Mann, and portion of a memoir.

Translations contains holograph and typescript drafts of Raphael's translation of Goethe's Faust: A Tragedy Part One and Faust: A Tragedy Part Two . Drafts are heavily annotated and corrected by Raphael and William A. Speck and Carl Schreiber, who assisted Raphael in her translation. An acting version of Faust: A Tragedy Part One included in the subseries is based on Raphael's translation. Other translations are The Parable and The Inferno of Dante Alighieri . Writings by others contains four drafts, including a writing on Historisch-kritische Nachrichten von Italien by J.J. Volkmann.
The working title for Goethe and the Philosophers' Stone: Symbolical Patterns in 'The Parable' and the Second Part of 'Faust' was Goethe and the Philosopher's Stone: A Psychological Interpretation .

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is organized into two subseries: Carl Gustav Jung Correspondence and Correspondence Arranged and Annotated by Alice Raphael.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains letters from Carl Gustav Jung to Alice Raphael regarding his theory of analysis and Raphael's attempts to publish her book, Goethe and the Philosophers' Stone: Symbolical Patterns in 'The Parable' and the Second Part of 'Faust' . Jung's letters are often brief.

The bulk of the correspondence regards Raphael's translations and her efforts to publish Faust: A Tragedy Part One and Part Two . Primary correspondents are Carl Schreiber and various publishers. Among the correspondents are Goethe scholars offering criticism of her work. The correspondence also includes one letter from Kahlil Gibran and one letter from Thomas Mann.

Raphael arranged, bound and annotated the correspondence after Curt von Faber du Faur's death in 1966 and in preparation for the donation of her papers to Yale University. Raphael added to the correspondence until 1969. Binders were disassembled during processing and binder labels are transcribed as folder titles. Throughout the correspondence, Raphael is often addressed by her married name of Eckstein.
Correspondence can also be found in Series VII, Correspondence with Yale Collection of German Literature.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Accompanied by photograph of Jung, Jung's memorial service program, and a clipping

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Accompanied by Raphael's 1968 notes on the scrapbook and her friendship with Curt von Faber du Faur; contains color pencil drawings by Raphael; three pieces for voice and piano by Raphael; "Now Like a Lantern" song, words by Alice Raphael and piano music by A. Walter Kramer; pamphlet on Kramer's music; and signed piano music by Louis Gruenberg; and commercial phonodisc sound recording of solo voice and piano. Scrapbook disassembled during processing.

Correspondence with Yale Collection of German Literature

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged chronologically by correspondent.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence with Yale Collection of German Literature contains correspondence between Alice Raphael and curators of the Yale Collection of German Literature. The correspondence documents Raphael's relationships with the curators as she worked on her translations of Faust: A Tragedy Part One and Two , her work as a Goethe scholar, and the donation of her books and papers to Yale University. Correspondence between curator Christa Sammons and Raphael's daughter Alice Wolff regards additional papers donated to Yale after Raphael's death.

did.unittitle: Letters from Alice Wolff to Christa Sammons
Photograph album of Eckstein family and farm in Greenwich, CT
